results.title: Tales of Beatrix Potter
results.creator_credit: Richard Goodwin, EMI/Parlophone and Reginald Mills
results.brief_description: Dancers of the Royal Ballet perform classic stories from the tales of Beatrix Potter bringing to life many of her best-loved characters - Mrs Tiggy-Winkle, Pigling Bland, Squirrel Nutkin and many more. They were the tales we loved as children and still hold with great affection as adults. Brilliantly designed by Christine Edzard, and beautifully danced by some of the great names of the Royal Ballet. This is one of the most charming and ingenious ballet films of recent years.

results.title: Swing time
results.creator_credit: George Stevens, Pandro S. Berman and RKO Radio Pictures
results.brief_description: Swing time was the sixth film made by Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers together. The story is slight, but quite delightful, bringing Fred and Ginger together, then keeping them apart until the last time we hear “A fine romance”. Astaire plays a dancer out of work, and Rogers is a dancing teacher - he pretends that he cannot dance so that he may be taught by Rogers.

results.title: Sweet Charity
results.creator_credit: Bob Fosse, Robert Arthur and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: Charity Hope Valentine (Shirley MacLaine) works as an erotic dancer and sometimes prostitute and is constantly unlucky in love. Whatever the disasters in her lovelife, she compensates with a rich fantasy life in which she dreams of meeting a man who will take her away from the sleazy world of the dancehalls. Based on a stage musical scripted by Neil Simon, which in turn was based on Federico Fellini’s “Nights of Cabiria.” “Sweet Charity” is a highly enjoyable screen musical which points to the new direction the musical film was to take in the ‘70’s. Fosse maintains the Broadway plot but he choreographs a stunning series of dance routines around the songs “Big Spender”, “There’s Got to be Something Better than This”, “If My Friends Could See Me Now” and a wonderfully hippie version of “Rhythm of Life” sung by a New Age minister played by Sammy Davis Jr. In “Sweet Charity” Bob Fosse is beginning the experimentation with dance and music which was to lead to his groundbreaking work in “Cabaret.”

results.title: Suture
results.creator_credit: David Siegel, Scott McGehee and Kino-Korsakoff
results.brief_description: Clay is briefly re-acquainted with his half-brother Vincent at their father’s funeral. Vincent, wanting to flee the country, stages an accident meant to look like his own death, but substitutes Clay in his place. Remarkable, Clay survives the explosion, although he now suffers amnesia. With the help of a plastic surgeon and a psychoanalyst, he is ‘restored’ to an identity that was never his, Vincent’s. As Clay, now Vincent, begins to enjoy a new lease on life and new identity, he realises that he is suspected of murder. What may seem like a standard thriller is given a subversive spin by having Clay played by a black actor and Vincent by a white actor and having no-one during the course of the film commenting on it. The film explores the concept of personal and racial identity as well as that of social construct with a great sense of irony. Stephen Soderbergh was the film’s executive producer. Cast includes Dennis Haysbert, Michael Harris, Mel Harris, Sab Shimono and Dina Merrill.

results.title: Surviving Picasso
results.creator_credit: James Ivory, David L. Wolper, Ismail Merchant, Wolper Productions and Merchant Ivory Productions
results.brief_description: One of the 20th century’s most influential painters, Picasso was also notorious for destroying the lives of those who loved him. Of the five major loves in his life, only one was strong enough to withstand his mad brilliance and walk away intact. Francoise Gilot (Natascha McElhone) was 23 years old when Picasso saw her in a bistro and invited her home. They become lovers and have a 10-year affair that produces his children Claude and Paloma. During their relationship Picasso (Anthony Hopkins) proved himself a brilliant artist and an appalling human being. Narcissistic, self-centered, cruel and sadistically manipulative, he treated his paint brushes better than he did his women, most of whom emerged from his grasp broken husks of their former selves. The screen play by Ruth Prawer Jhabvala is adapted from the biography by Ariana Stassinopoulos Huffington. Cast includes Julianne Moore, Joss Ackland, Peter Eyre, Jane Lapotaire, Bob Peck, Diane Venora and Joan Plowright.

results.title: Superman II
results.creator_credit: Richard Lester, Pierre Spengler and Alexander Salkind and Ilya Salkind Productions
results.brief_description: In this sequel to “Superman: the movie”, the Man of Steel’s romance with Lois Lane begins to blossom just as three villains from Krypton - who all have powers to match Superman’s - arrive on Earth with the intention of destroying the planet. With the help of arch-criminal Lex Luthor, the three locate Superman and when the truth is uncovered about Superman’s past - he being the son of their jailer - they seek to avenge Jor-El by killing his only son. The battle between Good and Evil culminates in a spectacular duel above Metropolis, and ends back at Superman’s home, where with a tricky manoeuvre, Superman restores order and peace on Earth. Cast includes: Christopher Reeve, Margot Kidder, Gene Hackman and Terrence Stamp.

results.title: Superfly
results.creator_credit: Sig Shore, Warner Bros Pictures and Gordon Parks Jr
results.brief_description: In the early seventies, mirroring the influential defiant culture of the Black Panthers there developed a uniquely “black” cinema in the United States. Featuring gritty street-wise characters, funk music and liberal doses of sex and violence, this genre quickly developed the name “blaxploitation” - a cinema directed to, and for, largely urban Afro-American audiences. Gordon Parks Jr’s “Superfly” is one of the most important films of the genre, as it unapologetically refused to compromise to white audience expectations. The hero, Priest, is a tough pimp and drug trafficker, who snorts cocaine throughout the movie and has little time for white people and their rules. The film follows his misadventures as he attempts to go straight in a world where the straights don’t want him. With limited resources, Parks Jr manages to create a highly entertaining and fast-paced thriller, fuelled by a brutal lead performance by Ron O’Neal and a stunning score by soul and funk musician, Curtis Mayfield.

results.title: Sunset Boulevard
results.creator_credit: Billy Wilder, Charles Brackett and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: This scathing film about Hollywood morality stars William Holden as an aspiring screenwriter who becomes a gigolo for fading movie Goddess, Norma Desmond (Gloria Swanson). A beauty of the silent screen she now remains isolated in her Los Angeles mansion, remembering the days when her fame was celebrated throughout the world. With a cynical, erudite script and some of Wilder’s best direction, “Sunset Boulevard” is a classic about the decay of Hollywood’s Golden Age. As the central character willing to prostitute himself in order to succeed, Holden is excellent but it is Swanson who gives one of the screen’s greatest performances as the demented, dangerous Norma. Her final scene is unforgettable.

results.title: Sunday Too Far Away
results.creator_credit: Ken Hannam, Matt Carroll, Gil Brealey and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: One of the few Australian feature films in which the narrative is centred on the portrayal of workers on the job - a group of shearers working on an outback station in 1955 in the months leading to the nine months shearers’ strike. While the gun shearer played by Jack Thompson is the central character, the focus of this episodic and unsentimental drama is on the communal values of the group rather than on those of the individual. Cinemaphotography by Geoff Burton. Cast also includes Max Cullen, Peter Cummins, John Ewart, John Hargreaves, Sean Scully, Ken Shorter, Gregory Apps.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ken Hannam, Matt Carroll, Gil Brealey and South Australian Film Corporation
results.description:
One of the few Australian feature films in which the narrative is centred on the portrayal of workers on the job, tins this case a group of shearers working on an Outback station in 1955, in the months leading to the nine-month shearers’ strike. While the gun shearer played by Jack Thompson is the central character, the focus of this episodic and unsentimental drama is on the communal values of the group rather than on those of the individual.

Cinematography by Geoff Burton.

Cast also includes Max Cullen, Peter Cummins, John Ewart, John Hargreaves, Sean Scully, Ken Shorter, Gregory Apps.

results.title: Summerfield
results.creator_credit: Ken Hannam, Patricia Lovell and Clare Beach Films
results.brief_description: When a newcomer arrives in a small, secluded town to discover that the former teacher has disappeared, he probes into the mystery and becomes more and more intrigued by the inhabitants of a forbidding house called Summerfield. Eventually, the secrets of Summerfield are revealed in a dramatic ending with a shock twist. Directed by Ken Hannam (director of ‘Sunday Too Far Away’) and starring, Nick Tate, Elizabeth Alexander and John Waters, ‘Summerfield’ was shot on location at Victoria’s Phillip and Churchill Islands.
